    Furazans in Medicinal Chemistry

    • Ross S. Mancini*
      Ross S. Mancini
      Treventis Corporation, Toronto, Ontario M5T 0S8, Canada
      *Email: [email protected]
      More by Ross S. Mancini
      View Biography
      • ,

      Christopher J. Barden
      Treventis Corporation, Toronto, Ontario M5T 0S8, Canada

    Abstract

    Incorporation of heterocycles into drug molecules can enhance physical properties and biological activity. A variety of heterocyclic groups is available to medicinal chemists, many of which have been reviewed in detail elsewhere. Oxadiazoles are a class of heterocycle containing one oxygen and two nitrogen atoms, available in three isomeric forms. While the 1,2,4- and 1,3,4-oxadiazoles have seen widespread application in medicinal chemistry, 1,2,5-oxadiazoles (furazans) are less common. This Review provides a summary of the application of furazan-containing molecules in medicinal chemistry and drug development programs from analysis of both patent and academic literature. Emphasis is placed on programs that reached clinical or preclinical stages of development. The examples provided herein describe the pharmacology and biological activity of furazan derivatives with comparative data provided where possible for other heterocyclic groups and pharmacophores commonly used in medicinal chemistry.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Heterocycles are ubiquitous in medicinal chemistry and materials science.(1,2) Incorporation of heterocyclic groups into molecules can generate binding interactions with a biological target or serve as a linker to generate favorable geometric conformations. The presence of oxygen and nitrogen atoms often polarizes the ring system and has been used to optimize physical properties such as solubility or crystal morphology. Heterocycles are also used as functional group replacements (bioisosteres) for carboxylates, nitriles, esters, carbamates, etc. to optimize drug-likeness of the compounds.(3)
    Oxadiazoles are a class of five-membered heterocycles containing one oxygen and two nitrogen atoms, having interesting biological activity and thermodynamic properties.(4−7) 1,2,4- and 1,3,4-oxadiazoles are used extensively in the development of bioactive molecules, yet incorporation of 1,2,5-oxadiazoles (furazans) is less common;(5,7) 1,2,3-oxadiazoles are unstable and prone to ring-opening processes. Furazans are unique in that substituents on the ring system are vicinal, having different geometry relative to the 1,2,4- and 1,3,4-isomers; fused-bicyclic ring systems are possible with furazans but not with 1,2,4- or 1,3,4-oxadiazoles. Furazans are also more polarized than other oxadiazoles given the clustered nature of the heteroatoms. These physical properties have been particularly useful in the development of high-energy density materials.(8)
    The synthesis and reactivity of furazans and their derivatives has previously been reviewed in detail,(9−14) but limited information regarding the biological activity of furazans is provided; biological activity of furazan-N-oxides (furoxans) has also been reviewed.(15) In this Review, we provide a detailed summary of the application and scope of furazan-containing molecules in medicinal chemistry and drug discovery. Emphasis is placed on research programs that reached clinical or preclinical stages of development. Analysis of both patent and academic literature was performed to illustrate how furazan derivatives identified as hit/lead chemotypes progress through lead optimization and preclinical stages of the drug development process. Examples where the furazans provide an advantage over other heterocyclic systems are highlighted, in addition to examples where the furazan chemotype was abandoned during development. This report provides a comprehensive illustration of the pharmacology and biological activity of furazan derivatives with comparative data provided for other drug-like pharmacophores used in medicinal chemistry.

    Physical Properties

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    1,2,5-Oxadiazoles have unique physical and electronic properties relative to the 1,2,4- and 1,3,4-isomers.(1) Differences in lipophilicity,(5) basicity,(16−18) and magnitude of the dipole moment(5,12,19−23) are observed (Figure 1). Furazans are highly inductive, comparable to a trifluoromethyl or tetrazolyl group(13,24,25) (Figure 2). The unique properties of furazans can impart interesting pharmacology to drug-like molecules. Examples are provided in the following sections.

    Furazans as Bioisosteres

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Nitrobenzene Bioisostere

    Benzofurazans are a known bioisostere for nitro aromatics. Both the furazan and nitro groups exert a high degree of electron-withdrawing character (Figure 2), but the absence of formal charges in the furazan may be advantageous when optimizing “drug-likeness” (activity, selectivity, stability). Most importantly, the nitro group has been identified as a toxicophore,(26) and removal or replacement at the earliest stage of compound development is routine practice.
    Merck employed nitro-to-furazan isosterism to reduce the human ether-à-go-go related gene (hERG) toxicity of novel renal outer medullary potassium channel (ROMK) inhibitors(27−29) (Figure 3, compounds 11–18); Novartis used a similar strategy to derisk a nitrobenzene-containing inhibitor (19) of phosphodiesterase type 4D (PDE4D),(30) generating preclinical lead NVP-ABE171 with improved activity/selectivity profile. Nitrobenzene-containing neuroprotective agents(31) identified by Treventis were also amenable to bioisosteric replacement during lead optimization(32,33) (Figure 3).
    A balance of electronegativity and sterics may rationalize the observed bioisosterism of benzofurazans for nitro-aromatics. A structure–activity relationship (SAR) study reported by Ijzermann et al. (Grüenthal GmbH, University of Leiden) observed that other benzo-fused heterocycles (benzisoxazole, benzisothiazole, benzimidazole, benzothiazole) were less potent than benzofurazan analogues of nitrobenzylthioinosine(34,35) (Figure 4). Obreque-Balboa et al. investigated the replacement of a 4-nitro group found in selective ABCC1 receptor ligand 21 with a variety of electron withdrawing groups (EWGs)(36) (Table 1); the benzofurazan (22h) was more potent than other derivatives (nitrile, CF3, ester, triflate) and maintained selectivity over ABCB1 and ABCG2 isoforms. However, bioisosterism of the furazan is dependent on the pharmacology of the system, and exceptions to the trends described here have been reported. Nitro groups in the ROMK inhibitors identified by Merck were more tolerant of other functional group replacements.(27−29)
    Table 1. Replacement of a Nitro Group in Selective ABCC1 Receptor Ligand 21
    compoundRIC50 (ABCC1) (μM)IC50 (ABCB1) (μM)IC50 (ABCG2) (μM)
    214-(NO2)-C6H413.2no effecta87.8
    22a4-(CN)-C6H426.7>10099.7
    22b3,4-(F)2-C6H338.058.566.6
    22c4-(CF3)-C6H419.831.3>100
    22d4-(SCF3)-C6H420.836.6>100
    22e4-(CO2CH3)-C6H458.3>100>100
    22f4-(SO2CH3)-C6H4>100no effectano effecta
    22g4-(SO2CF3)-C6H422.7>100>100
    22h5-benzofurazan11.3no effectano effecta
    a

    No observed inhibition of transporter activity at concentrations up to 100 μM.

    Carboxylic Acid Bioisostere

    Hydroxyfurazan was proposed as a bioisostere of the carboxylic acid group in 2006. A series of papers(37−41) demonstrates the hydroxyfurazan moiety is highly ionizable, with pKa values similar to the parent carboxylic acids. The seminal report by Lolli et al. investigated hydroxyfurazan bioisosteres of the neurotransmitter γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) as novel biomimetics;(40,41) bioisosteres of glutamate (Glu) are described in a later report.(38) As shown in Figure 5, the furazan analogues maintain receptor affinity albeit with decreased potency.(38,40) Computational analysis of 23 suggests an intramolecular hydrogen bond (H-bond) between the ammonium group and the furazan N5 stabilizes the active conformation; this interaction was not observed in the related isoxazole derivative but could be observed to a lesser extent for a 1,2,5-thiadiazole analogue.(41) The calculated dipole moment of 3-hydroxyfurazan was found to have different magnitude and directionality relative to the model substrate propenonic acid: it was suggested the decreased affinity of 23 relative to GABA may be due to less “carboxy-like” character of the ionizable group. However, the pKa of 23 and GABA is comparable and both exist in the Zwitterionic state at physiological pH.
    A furazan bioisostere of indomethacin (25) enhanced selectivity for aldo-ketoreductase (AKR), an oncology drug target, over cyclooxygenase (COX) with minimal impact on the physical properties and antiproliferative effects (Table 2); a moderate increase in lipophilicity was observed.(42,43) Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as indomethacin are known to have anticancer activity, but their efficacy is limited by adverse gastrointestinal and cardiovascular responses related to effects on COX activity.(44) Similar observations were reported for a series of dihydroorotate dehydrogenase (DHODH) inhibitors(39) (Figure 6); isosteric replacement of the cyclopentenyl ring in 28 and 29, a key piece of the pharmacophore, having optimal geometry for ion paring of the carboxylate with Arg-136 and occupancy of the biphenyl in a hydrophobic pocket,(45) maintained activity against DHODH in furazan analogues 26 and 27. The difference in activity may be due to differences in species origin of the DHODH enzyme (human vs rat) or the conditions of the assay,(46) as in vitro activity of the furazan derivatives was comparable to known DHODH inhibitors DuP-785 (brequinar) and A771726 (teriflunomide) in experiments performed by the authors.(39)
    Table 2. Physical Properties and Biological Activity of Indomethacin and Hydroxyfurazan Bioisostere 25
    a

    Solubility was determined in simulated intestinal fluid.

    Urea Bioisostere

    A less established bioisosterism is 4,5-diaminofurazans as “urea equivalents.” This approach was investigated in a series of papers(47−50) describing analogues of ranitidine (Figure 7). Replacement of the pseudourea moiety with the aminofurazan (30) maintained histamine type-2 (H2) receptor antagonism, and a series of more potent analogues (e.g., 31) was eventually disclosed.(47,48) Limited examples exist in the literature which employ the diaminofurazan as a urea bioisostere; given the recent recall of ranitidine (Zantac)(51) this approach may be worth exploring in future drug discovery programs.

    Enhancement of Activity and Pharmacokinetics

    Oleanolic acid (OA) is a natural product with a range of biological effects, including some anticancer activity.(52) However, OA does not inhibit leukemia cell proliferation. A report by Ng et al. identified the furazan derivative olean-12-eno[2,3-c][1,2,5]oxadiazol-28-oic acid (OEOA), having antileukemic activity in vitro(53) (Table 3). OEOA does not affect the growth of human neonatal keratinocytes, suggesting the antileukemic activity of OEOA is not due to a general cytotoxic effect of the compound in cell culture. Both OA and OEOA are detected in mouse plasma following intraperitoneal (i.p.) administration, but OEOA shows ca. twofold improvement in half-life (t1/2).
    Table 3. Half-Life and Antiproliferative Effects of OA and OEOA against Leukemia Cell Lines
    It was shown that OEOA induces cell cycle arrest of leukemia-derived cells (K562) in the G1 phase via reduction of Cyclin D1, Cdk4 and Cdk6 protein expression, preventing transition into S phase and promoting erythroid differentiation and eventual senescence (“differentiation therapy”). Kinase inhibitors such as imatinib display a related mechanism of action (MoA) but operate at the post-translational level, targeting protein activity rather than its expression; resistance to imatinib treatment has been observed in some patients. The complementary MoA of OEOA is noteworthy.

    Neurodegenerative and Neurological Disorders

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A significant challenge in treating neurological disorders is the requisite exposure of a drug in the brain or nervous system. Penetration of the blood-brain barrier or blood-cerebrospinal fluid barrier is known to be challenging; drug therapies targeting disorders of the central nervous system (CNS) typically require a higher degree of lipophilic character to enable passive diffusion into the brain. Benzofurazans occupy an interesting chemical space, balancing lipophilic character with a high polarization and inductive effect from the oxadiazole moiety (Figure 1). Examples of benzofurazans disclosed in drug discovery programs focused on CNS disorders are presented here.
    Patents from Treventis describe benzofurazan derivatives which inhibit the aggregation of pathogenic amyloid beta (Aβ) and tau proteins, with claims that the compounds are useful to treat neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and other tauopathies(32,33) (Figure 8). Inhibition of Aβ and tau protein fibrillization was demonstrated in vitro (biochemical aggregation assays), and inhibition of Aβ oligomerization is also disclosed;(32) prefibrillar aggregates are highly neurotoxic and are implicated in AD pathology.(54) Hit compounds were identified using a proprietary virtual screening platform (CCM; Common Conformational Morphology), which models amyloid aggregation. In silico screening of 10.8 million commercially available compounds against CCM followed by in vitro screening (Aβ and tau aggregation assays) of top hits identified a series of nitrobenzene derivatives (similar to TRV1140, Figure 3) with good activity profiles. A derisking strategy included replacement of the nitro group (a known toxicophore(26)) with a variety of known bioisosteres;(31) the benzofurazans maintained activity of the parent compounds and showed favorable ADMET profiles. Dose-dependent in vivo target engagement of both Aβ and tau oligomers has been demonstrated in several transgenic AD model systems.
    TRV1442 (Figure 8) has also shown proof-of-concept efficacy as a treatment for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).(55) Treatment with TRV1442 restored motor function and decreased neurodegeneration in multiple animal models; growth defects in neuromuscular junctions associated with disease pathology were reduced, preserving synaptic function. It was proposed that TRV1442 engages a target at the presynaptic level central to disease pathology, as efficacy was observed in SOD1, TDP-43, and C9orf72 model systems of ALS.
    Forum Pharmaceuticals (formerly EnVivo) claimed modulators of γ-secretase activity as a therapeutic agent for AD.(56−58) Modulation, rather than inhibition, of γ-secretase was shown to decrease production of pathogenic Aβ1–42 in favor of shorter, “less pathogenic” Aβ peptides while avoiding the known side effects associated with γ-secretase inhibition.(59) A benzofurazan derivative (Figure 9, compound 32) was identified as a lead compound with submicromolar EC50 values for Aβ1–42 reduction in vitro;(57) development of a more potent, nonfurazan derivative (33) produced clinical candidate EVP-0015962(59) (Figure 9). Despite promising results in preclinical investigation, the program was discontinued following results from a phase II clinical trial (clinicaltrials.gov; NCT01661673). A complementary approach was reported by Mitsubishi Pharma, where inhibition of glycogen synthase kinase-3β (GSK-3β) reduced levels of phospho-tau and the associated neurofibrillary tangles (another disease pathology marker in AD). Lead compounds displayed nanomolar IC50 values for GSK-3β inhibition and produced dose-dependent reductions in the amount of phospho-tau in vitro(60−62) (Figure 9, compounds 34–38). Further development, in partnership with Sanofi-Aventis, identified a novel chemotype(63,64) and preclinical candidate SAR502250;(65) clinical trials in AD were not pursued, and the program was discontinued.
    Isradipine (Figure 10), a dihydropyridine (DHP) calcium channel antagonist used as an antihypertensive agent, was evaluated in clinical trials to treat Parkinson’s disease (PD).(66,67) The relationship between calcium homeostasis and PD pathology is well-established(68) and isradipine is neuroprotective in in vitro(69) and in vivo(70) models. Unfortunately, isradipine failed to slow the clinical progression of early stage PD(67) in humans (STEADY-PD). The maximum tolerated dose of isradipine(66) may be insufficient to elicit a therapeutic response; L-type calcium channels of the substantia nigra, the proposed drug target for PD, are less sensitive to DHP antagonism than L-type calcium channels found in smooth muscle(71) (drug target for hypertension). Isradipine has also been proposed as a treatment for AD,(72−75) but further research is needed to validate these observations, as related DHP calcium channel blockers nilvadipine and nimodipine (Figure 10) have shown limited efficacy in clinical trials.(76−78) Clinical trials exploring the potential of isradipine to mitigate substance abuse and addiction observed no effect on cocaine dependency or cocaine response.(79)
    RespireRx (formerly Cortex) has developed benzofurazanyl amide derivatives as α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid (AMPA) receptor modulators (Figure 11). These “Ampakines” are orally bioavailable and enhance excitatory neuronal communication processes.(80,81) The benzofurazans are considered low impact (type II) Ampakines, increasing response amplitude of AMPA-mediated synapses.(82) Glutamatergic neurotransmission is involved in learning and memory,(83,84) with reduced or impaired glutamatergic signaling contributing to cognitive dysfunction.(85) Preclinical investigation has demonstrated that acute administration of Ampakine CX691 (Farampator, Figure 11) increased the concentration of acetylcholine and dopamine in the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex (learning/memory),(86) with chronic administration increasing the expression of neurotrophins (neuroplasticity).(86,87) The development of Ampakines as cognitive enhancers is an active area of research.(81,88)
    Significant improvements in the pharmacokinetic (PK) profile of the benzofurazan derivative CX691 over the first generation benzopyrazine CX516 (Ampalex, Figure 11) were observed in phase I clinical trials(89,90) (Table 4). Phase II studies were initiated to investigate Ampakines as a therapeutic agent for schizophrenia, but the programs were eventually terminated.(91,92) Research programs in AD,(93) autism,(94) clinical depression,(95) and sleep depravation(96,97) have been pursued with variable degrees of success and limited human data reported. However, a phase IIa clinical trial for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)(98) (NCT03375021) demonstrated CX717 (Figure 11) produced a beneficial effect on alertness and amelioration of cognitive deficits. The drug was found to be safe and well-tolerated at the therapeutic dose (800 mg) with low incidence of adverse events (reported events include nausea, headache, dizziness). Further clinical investigation is yet to be reported.
    Table 4. PK Parameters of Ampakine CX516 (Benzopyrazine) and CX691(Benzofurazan) in Healthy Elderly Humans
    parameterCX516CX691
    effective dose900 mg500 mg
    Cplasma (1 h)8.3 μMca. 2.5 μM
    Cplasma (2 h)4.0 μMca. 2.0 μM
    RespireRx has also demonstrated that Ampakine administration can reduce the incidence of lethal apneas during periods of opioid-induced analgesia,(99) apnea of prematurity(100) and substance abuse (alcohol and barbituates).(101) Ampakine coadministration could significantly increase the safety window of opioid-induced analgesia in clinical practice;(102) CX717 and CX1739 (Figure 11) have completed phase II clinical trials.(103,104) In a published report,(104) administration of CX717 (1.5 g) to healthy volunteers effectively reversed alfentanil-induced respiratory depression without affecting the analgesic effects of the opioid. Modulation of AMPA receptors in the pre-Bötzinger complex (generates respiratory drive(105,106)) rescues respiratory rhythms without antagonizing the effect of alfentanil on μ-opioid receptors.(107,108) Published literature for CX1739 in humans is currently unavailable. Development programs for CX717 and CX1739 have also been initiated for Pompe Disease(109) and spinal cord injury,(110,111) along with continued efforts toward use of Ampakines to treat cognitive dysfunction.(98) Other benzofurazan-derived Ampakines have been disclosed(98,112−114) (e.g., compounds 39–43, Figure 11) and prodrug approaches are also being investigated.(98,115,116)
    Merck has reported a class of nonpeptide reversible inhibitors of caspase-3 (casp-3).(117) Peptide-based inhibitors are known to be neuroprotective in models of hypoxia-ischemia,(118) but display irreversible pan-caspase inhibition and off-target effects(119) which limit their utility. A significant advance in the development of Merck’s casp-3 inhibitors(120,121) was the incorporation of a furazan moiety, where enhanced activity and selectivity was observed relative to other heterocycles (thiadiazole, pyrazole, triazole, 1,2,4- and 1,3,4-oxadiazoles).(120) The furazan is proposed to possess optimal steric and electronic requirements required for casp-3 selectivity; a more polar and conformationally restricted binding pocket is reported for casp-3 relative to other caspases.(122) Merck’s casp-3 inhibitors are reported to be 50–1000-fold greater than peptide-based caspase inhibitors in vitro(123) (Figure 12).
    Preclinical studies with M826 (rodent model of hypoxia-ischemia) demonstrated near complete inhibition casp-3 activation in vivo with a concomitant decrease in brain lesions and tissue loss.(123) Further evaluation in rodent model of Huntington’s disease(124) demonstrated M826 is moderately neuroprotective; a reduction in lesion volume (39%) and amount of striatum lesioned (33%) is observed. In this model, only a 66% reduction of activated casp-3 is observed despite a striatal concentration of 32.3 μM 1 h postinjection (neuronal cell EC50 = 0.12 μM) and sufficient concentrations still detected at 6 h postinjection (Table 5). Secondary pathways not involving casp-3 are thought to be responsible, at least in part, for the observed neurodegeneration.(123,124) The efficacy of altered dose regimens or repeated doses of M826 to increase the neuroprotective effect was not evaluated in this report. Further, M826 is not CNS-penetrant and required intrastriatal (i.str.) injection.
    Table 5. PK of M826 in the Malonate-Induced Mouse Model of Huntington’s Disease
    parametervalue
    dose (i.str.)1.5 nmol
    Cmax (1 h)32.3 μM
    conc (6 h)5.1 μM
    conc (24 h)0.10 μM
    t1/23 h

    Inflammatory Disorders

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    (Benzo)furazan inhibitors of the p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) have been claimed as therapeutic agents useful in treating inflammatory disorders. p38 MAPK is an attractive drug target given its involvement in the production of inflammatory mediators, but clinical development of p38 MAPK inhibitors has proven challenging (low efficacy, toxicity). Many p38 MAPK inhibitors target the ATP-binding pocket, a common domain in a variety of kinases, perhaps leading to some of the observed off-target effects.(125) Second generation inhibitors of p38 MAPK which target allosteric sites have been developed, but upregulation of compensatory signaling cascades involving Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) and extracellular signal-regulated kinase 1/2 (ERK1/2) has been observed.
    A benzofurazan chemotype developed by Mendez and coworkers (Figure 13) targets a docking grove of p38 MAPK rather than the ATP-binding site, preventing the association of regulator proteins and inhibiting phosphorylation (activation) by upstream kinases. This, in turn, prevents phosphorylation of downstream substrates by p38 MAPK, reducing the inflammatory response.(126,127) A compensatory increase in JNK and ERK1/2 activation was not observed. Nitro-substituted benzofurazans are considered a pan-assay interference (PAINS) motif having promiscuous off-target activity,(128) yet FGA-19 is nontoxic in cell cultures (up to 100 μM) and showed minimal activity against a panel screen of related kinases. Preclinical models of inflammatory pain (acute and chronic) have demonstrated efficacy; carrageenan-induced inflammatory response was suppressed in vivo with concomitant resolution of the associated hyperalgesia. A more potent and sustained analgesic effect was produced using FGA-19 relative to known p38 MAPK inhibitor SB239063 (Table 6).
    Table 6. Analgesic Effect of FGA-19 and SB239063 in Vivo
    compounddose (nmol)arelief onset (h)relief duration
    FGA-193.28<0.5>5 days
    FGA-191.6416 h
    SB23906313.616 h
    a

    Compounds were administered by intrathecal injection 6 days postcarrageenan insult.

    A related class of furazanopyrazine-derived p38 MAPK inhibitors from Allinky Biopharma (Figure 13, compounds 45–52) operate via a similar MoA, but also inhibit the functionally related JNK MAPK.(129,130) Compound 47 was also shown to be CNS-penetrant in vivo;(130) activated p38 MAPK in the spinal cord is associated with chronic inflammatory pain. A protective effect was demonstrated in neuronal stem cells on exposure to inflammatory cytokines (Table 7). These preliminary results are encouraging for conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and chronic inflammatory pain, but further development has yet to be reported.
    Table 7. In Vitro and in Vivo Profile of 47
     in vitroin vivoc
    dosep38 inhibition (%)JNK inhibition (%)reduction of TNFα (%)a% rescue of neuronsbCplasma (2 h, μM)Cbrain (2 h, μM)
    10 μM99987451  
    1.0 μM37495133  
    10 mg/kg (IV)    0.430.80
    a

    Measured in THP-1 monocytes.

    b

    Exposure to cytokines.

    c

    PK data were measured in mouse. IV = intravenous.

    Inhibition of PDE4 to treat chronic inflammatory disorders like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) was proposed as an alternative to glucocorticosteroids. Cilomilast (GlaxoSmithKline) completed several phase III clinical trials for COPD,(131) but development was eventually terminated. Roflumilast (ALTANA) is approved for treatment/management of COPD. NVP-ABE171, developed by Novartis, is a benzofurazan-containing PDE4 inhibitor selective for the type-D isoform.(30,132) This compound is orally bioavailable when administered as the N-methyl-d-glucamine salt and produced a significant reduction in inflammatory response in preclinical models of COPD, with efficacy similar to roflumilast(133,134) (Table 8). However, PDE4 inhibitors are known to have a narrow therapeutic window and reliable dosing is paramount to a safe therapeutic response. The low solubility of NVP-ABE171 prompted further development focused on improving solubility and reproducibility of the PK profile (Table 9). Clinical lead 53 was ultimately selected for phase I profiling.(135,136)
    Table 8. Comparison of in Vitro Activity for PDE4 Inhibitors Developed by Novartis (NVP-ABE171, 53) GlaxoSmithKline (Cilomilast), and ALTANA (Roflumilast)
    a

    EC50 values were determined in peripheral blood mononuclear cells stimulated with lipopolysaccharide (LPS).

    b

    LPS-induced inflammation (mouse).

    c

    Ovalbumin-induced lung inflammation (rat).

    Table 9. Solubility-Driven Optimization of NVP-ABE171 to Clinical Candidate 53a
    parameterNVP-ABE17153
    solubility (pH 6.8)6.2 μM2.6 mM
    Cmax (μM)2.44.6
    Tmax (min)210200
    t1/2 (h)129
    AUC (μM·min)5234408
    F (%)852
    a

    PK parameters were determined in rat.

    GlaxoSmithKline reported a furazanyl benzimidazole pharmacophore with broad spectrum kinase inhibition activity(137−139) (Figure 14, compound 61). SAR and in silico modeling identified key H-bonding interactions between the aminofurazan and the highly conserved hinge region of ATP-binding site;(140) the C3-amino group acts as a H-bond donor with the carbonyl of Asp-132 and the furazan N2 acts as an H-bond acceptor with Ile-134. An intramolecular H-bond between the aminofurazan and imidazole nitrogen was also proposed to rationalize the observed coplanarity of the biaromatic system. An additional H-bonding interaction with Lys-81 was achieved through introduction of a nitrogen atom at the 5-position of the benzimidazole, further increasing potency.
    Replacement of the furazan with amino-substituted isoxazole, pyridine, pyrazine or pyrazole heterocycles led to decreased activity (Figure 14, compounds 55–58), perhaps due to differences in the pKa and H-bonding character of the amino group. Removal of the amino group (60) or replacement with other H-bond donors (56 vs 59) abolished activity. A steric effect was also observed (57 vs 58) due to proximity of the “gate-keeper” Leu-131. Small alkyl substituents on the imidazole nitrogen occupy a lipophilic pocket formed by Val-53, Leu-55, Phe-348 and Leu-184, with ethyl and cyclopropyl groups showing favorable activity. Taken together, lead derivative 61 was identified as the optimal chemotype, showing broad-spectrum kinase inhibition activity (Figure 14).
    A lead optimization program identified selective inhibitors of mitogen and stress activated protein kinases 1 (MSK-1);(140,141) activation of MSK-1 by ERK and p38 MAPK pathways regulates the production of inflammatory mediators. The derivative SB-747651A (Figure 14) displays an enhanced selectivity profile relative to other MSK-1 inhibitors (H89, Ro 31-8220);(142) addition of a pendant basic amine moiety is proposed to interact with Glu-138 via ion pairing. The corresponding residues in GSK-3 and RSK-1 are Thr and Asp, respectively, which provides selectivity over these related kinases. Cell-based assays confirm that both MSK-1 and MSK-2 are efficiently inhibited by SB-747651A, resulting in decreased levels of downstream phosphorylation events; activation of upstream regulators ERK1/2, p38, and JNK MAPKs was unaffected. In vitro cellular responses (RNA transcription, cytokine production) to SB-747651A are replicated in MSK-1/2 knockout macrophages, providing a useful tool to study the role of MSK in inflammatory processes.

    Hypertension

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Isradipine (tradenames DynaCirc, Prescal; Figure 10) is a DHP calcium channel antagonist which targets L-type voltage-gated calcium channels found in vascular smooth muscle cells, preventing calcium flux into the cytoplasm. Contraction of smooth muscle is a calcium-dependent process; altering calcium flux in the vasculature produces a vasodilatory effect.(143) Isradipine is an effective treatment for chronic hypertension (monotherapy or in combination with other antihypertensives such as β-blockers) with a favorable hemodynamic profile and low incidence of adverse events.(144) The PK and efficacy of isradipine has been reviewed in detail.(143−145) The improved PK profiles of second-generation DHP calcium channel antagonists (isradipine, nimodipine, nicardipine, etc.) have enabled more favorable dosing regiments; for example, once daily controlled release or twice daily standard formulation oral tablets is standard-of-care for isradipine(145) (Table 10). Bioavailability of DHP therapeutics is low due to substantial first-pass metabolism; the improved half-life of the second-generation DHPs is noteworthy. Comparative studies between isradipine (benzofurazan) and nifedipine (nitrobenzene) have demonstrated greater efficacy of isradipine for treatment of essential hypertension.(144) A large clinical study (MIDAS) concluded that isradipine is more efficacious than hydrochlorothiazide (a diuretic) in reducing the rate of progression of atherosclerosis. Other clinical programs suggest isradipine is effective for treating congestive heart failure(146,147) and angina.(148,149) Chemical structures of some available DHP antihypertensive agents are given in Figure 10.
    Table 10. Dose, Half-Life, and Bioavailability of DHP Calcium Channel Antagonists Used in Treating Essential Hypertension
    drugstandard dose per day (oral)at1/2 (h)F (%)
    nifedipine (first gen.)40–80 mg (bid. or once daily sustained release)3.445
    isradipine5–10 mg (bid. or once daily sustained release)8.419
    nimodipine360 mg (60 mg every 4 h)0.912
    nicardipine20–60 mg (every 8 h or bid. sustained release)11.527
    nilvadipine8–16 mg (bid. or once daily sustained release)11.014
    nilvadipine8–16 mg (bid. or once daily sustained release)11.014
    a

    bid. = twice daily.

    Potassium channel activation is an alternative approach to modulate calcium-dependent muscle contraction. Increased potassium efflux results in hyperpolarisation of cell membrane, reducing calcium flux into the cytoplasm.(150) Potassium channel activators (PCAs) have been investigated as antihypertensives; most programs were terminated due to a narrow therapeutic window and poor tolerance in most patients. Benzofurazan analogues of the PCA levcromakalim (GlaxoSmithKline) were disclosed in a patent from Nissan Chemical Industries as therapeutic agents to treat hypertension and ischemic heart diseases(151) (Figure 15). The derivative NIP-121 was reported to have a more favorable activity profile than levcromakalim(152,153) (Table 11). Preclinical investigation demonstrated dose-dependent reductions in systemic blood pressure; tachycardia was observed, but could be prevented by combination with a β-blocker.(154) A comparative study of NIP-121 and nifedipine (a calcium channel antagonist) produced similar outcomes, but the dose of NIP-121 was 10-fold lower than nifedipine.(155) Nissan terminated the development of NIP-121 at the preclinical stage.
    Table 11. Antihypertensive Effect of PCAs NIP-121 and Levcromakalim in Anesthetized Dogsa
    compounddose (IV, μg/kg)mean aortic pressure reduction (%)coronary blood flow increase (%)
    NIP-1211.5–7.534.3
    levcromakalim5.0–11.233.3
    a

    Calculated from dose–response curves. IV = intravenous.

    Inhibition of Rho-associated coil-forming serine/threonine kinases (ROCKs) is an established treatment strategy for pulmonary hypertension; Rho kinase-mediated calcium sensitization is implicated in vasoconstriction. Up-regulation of ROCK activity results in smooth muscle constriction and is implicated in cardiovascular diseases. A furazanyl benzimidazole pharmacophore identified by GlaxoSmithKline is known to exhibit broad spectrum kinase inhibition.(137−139) The aminofurazan moiety is essential (Figure 14), forming two key H-bonding interactions in the hinge region of the ATP-binding site.(140) Development and SAR of the furazanyl benzimidazole pharmacophore is described above (see Inflammatory Disorders). Lead optimization revealed that addition of a pendant amide to the benzimidazole moiety enhanced selectivity for ROCK-1, leading to the discovery of orally bioavailable ROCK-1 inhibitors GSK269962A and SB-772077B (Figure 15) having good activity/selectivity profiles.(156−158) Administration of either GSK269962A or SB-772077B to hypertensive rats produced dose-dependent decreases in blood pressure with higher potency than established ROCK inhibitors Y-27632, SAR407899, and fasudil (Figure 15, Table 12), and only a modest decrease in blood pressure was observed in normotensive animals. Fasudil (Asahi Kasei Pharma) has proven efficacious in the treatment of pulmonary hypertension,(159,160) but the clinical efficacy of furazan-derived ROCK inhibitors has not been investigated; SAR407899 (Sanofi-Aventis) was in phase II clinical evaluation for patients with angina, but the trial was terminated due to low recruitment (NCT03236311).
    Table 12. Antihypertensive Effects of ROCK Inhibitors in Vitro and in Vivo
     in vitroin vivo
        ΔBP (mm/Hg)/ΔHR (bpm)a  
    drugIC50 VR (rat aorta)actin stress fiber inhibition (hASM)dose3 h6 h10 hΔPAP (mm Hg)bΔSAP (mm Hg)b
    SB-772077B39 nM3 μM1 mg/kg–20/+20–20/–40–5/–25  
    1 μmol/kg   –13–40
    GSK269962A35 nM3 μM1 mg/kg–20/+30–10/+100/0  
    Y-276321.4 μM30 μM10 mg/kg–25/+75–10/+10–5/0  
    1 μmol/kg   –10–32
    fasudil1.3 μM(177) 3 mg/kg–30/–50–20/–100/–10  
    SAR407899(177)122 nM 1 μmol/kg   –6–19
    a

    Spontaneously hypertensive rats.

    b

    U44619-induced hypertensive rats (acute changes). VR = vasorelaxation. hASM = human primary aortic smooth muscle cells; BP = blood pressure; HR = heart rate; bpm = beats per minute. PAP = pulmonary arterial pressure. SAP = systemic arterial pressure.

    Cancer

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Microtubule Targeting Agents (BAL101553)

    Microtubule targeting agents (MTAs) are potent inducers of apoptosis useful in treating cancer.(161) A novel class of MTA discovered by Aponetics(162) demonstrated apoptotic activity in multiple cancer cell lines. The furazan derivative BAL27862 (avanbulin), developed by Basilea Pharmaceuticals, was selected for clinical development(163,164) (Figure 16). BAL27862 is a competitive inhibitor of microtubule assembly (IC50 = 1.4 μM) which targets the colchicine binding site,(165) with potent antiproliferative activity observed in cancer cell lines resistant to established MTA chemotherapeutics.(166−169) Soluble prodrugs of BAL27862 were developed via conjugation with an amino acid residue.(170) Lysine derivative BAL101553 (lisavanbulin) was chosen for preclinical validation, and reports describing the MoA and preclinical efficacy have been published.(166,171−173)
    BAL10553 is currently undergoing phase I/IIa clinical evaluation in patients with advanced solid tumors and glioblastoma/high-grade glioma (NCT01397929, NCT02895360, NCT02490800) by intravenous (IV) and oral administration. Dose-escalation studies identified an effective dose of 30 mg/m2 (2-h IV infusion) with toxicities observed at doses >45 mg/m2.(174) Adverse responses include neurological and myocardial injury due to vascular disruption, with severity correlated with increasing Cmax values. A 48-h continuous infusion was developed to reduce the Cmax and increase the tolerability of the treatment;(175) higher doses (70 mg/m2) are tolerated with no apparent vascular toxicity(176) (Table 13). The relative bioavailability for oral administration of BAL101553 was found to be 80% (ratio of dose-normalized AUC for oral vs IV route). Combination therapy approaches are also under investigation to increase patient response rates: a phase I trial of BAL101553 with combination radiation therapy is being evaluated in glioblastoma patients (NCT03250299); preclinical data suggests the combination of BAL101553 with eribulin(178) or gemcitabine(179) markedly improves the efficacy of treatment.
    Table 13. Differences in PK and Vascular Effects for Administration of BAL101553 by Various Methods
    dose (route)duration of IV infusion (h)Cmax (ng/mL)AUC (ng·h/mL)AUC/CmaxΔsystolic BP (mm Hg)
    30 mg/m2 (IV)2267362013.6+10
    45 mg/m2 (IV)2356434012.2+20
    45 mg/m2 (IV)4877.7383049.3–5b
    70 mg/m2 (IV)48144858059.6+5b
    16 mg (p.o.)N/A131840064.1 
    20 mg (p.o.)aN/A13412 18090.9 
    a

    Grade 4 (serious, life-threatening) hyponatremia observed in 2/7 patients.

    b

    Change considered not significant. p.o. = per os (oral administration). N/A = not applicable.

    STAT Inhibitors

    Signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) is an established drug target in oncology, with considerable interest in small molecule inhibitors. However, there are currently no approved STAT3 inhibitors available on the market.(180) Ureido-furazan AVS-0288 was identified as a potent inhibitor of STAT3 activity;(181) SAR studies(182,183) identified MD77 as a promising lead compound (Figure 17), having antiproliferative effects against multiple cancer cell types(184) (Table 14). Computational docking of MD77 to the SH2 domain of STAT3 identified two key H-bonding interactions between the furazan and Arg-609. Replacement of the furazan with other heterocyclic systems (1,3,4-oxadiazole, isoxazole, imidazole, furan) was not tolerated;(185,186) highly electronegative systems (furazan) are proposed to enhance the binding interaction. Derivatives of MD77 have also been used as ligands for Pt(II) chloride to generate “dual-action” STAT3/DNA replication inhibitors(187) (Figure 17, compound 66). Reduction in tumor volume was comparable to cisplatin treatment with no associated weight loss (Table 15). A series of furazan-3-carboxylic acids are claimed as inhibitors of STAT5 (also implicated cancer progression) useful in treating acute myeloid leukemia(188) (Figure 17, compounds 67–69). Phosphorylation of STAT5 (but not expression) was reduced in vitro, producing dose-dependent reductions of downstream transcriptional activity. No effect on STAT3 expression or phosphorylation was observed.
    Table 14. Antiproliferative Effect of MD77a
    cancer typeEC50 (μM)
    leukemia0.84–2.8
    nonsmall cell lung carcinoma0.63–3.8
    colorectal2.2–3.8
    CNS-derived1.0–3.7
    melanoma0.87–4.3
    ovarian1.8–4.7
    renal1.7–6.8
    prostate1.4–3.5
    breast2.2–3.4
    a

    EC50 values were determined against >50 tumor cell lines.

    Table 15. Inhibition of Tumor Growth in Vivo for 66 and Cisplatin in Lewis Lung Carcinoma Xenograft Mice
    compounddose i.p. (mg/kg)tumor growth inhibition (%)weight loss (%)
    66308512
    cisplatin1.58827

    Inhibitors of Protein–Protein Interactions

    Inhibition of protein–protein interactions (PPIs) is challenging and was once considered “undruggable” using small molecules. However, delivery of high molecular weight therapeutics (peptides, biologics) is difficult, whereas small molecules are often permeable. Benzo-fused and pyrazine-fused furazan derivatives have been identified in multiple drug development programs as effective inhibitors of PPIs, with activity comparable to larger biomolecules. Ji and coworkers identified furazanopyrazines which inhibit β-catenin/T-cell factor (Tcf) dimerization;(189,190) hyperactivation of signaling pathways regulated by β-catenin is associated with the progression of various cancers and fibroses. The small molecule inhibitors show similar efficacy in vitro to a series of peptidomimetics(191) developed by the same group (Figure 18, compounds 70, 71); higher potency is observed in cell-free systems for the peptidomimetics, but activity in cell-based systems is comparable (related to drug permeability). Zhang et al. identified furazanopyrazines which inhibit the dimerization of survivin (signaling protein regulated by β-catenin).(192,193) Chemotherapeutics which target the transcription and expression of survivin show limited efficacy in clinical trials;(194) regulation of survivin at the protein level is a complementary approach. Inhibition of survivin dimerization and dissociation of preformed survivin dimers was demonstrated in cell-free systems, and lead compound LQZ-7F (Figure 18) showed efficacy in vitro in a variety of cancer cell lines (mRNA expression and protein synthesis are unaffected, supporting a MoA involving inhibition of PPIs).(192) LQZ-7F also reduced tumor volume (ca. 30%) in xenograft mice and was well-tolerated even with repeated dosing.
    The heterodimerization of cMyc-Max is another PPI implicated in cancer progression (overexpression, deregulation of cMyc).(195) A series of nitrobenzofurazans were developed as selective inhibitors of cMyc-Max dimerization, having no effect on Max-Max homodimerization(196,197) (Figure 19). The compound 10074-G4 was shown to inhibit dimerization through binding to cMyc monomers; the nitrobenzofurazan engages Arg-366 and Arg-367, while the biphenyl extends into a hydrophobic domain formed by Phe-375 and Ile-381. The furazan and the nitro group were proposed as key parts of the pharmacophore;(198) replacement of the benzofurazan with a benzene or reduction of the nitro group to an amino group abolished activity. However, replacement of the nitro group with a trifluoroacetamido group showed activity comparable to 10074-G5. Additional SAR of the furazan moiety was not disclosed. In vivo profiling of 10074-G5 showed limited efficacy due to dose-limiting solubility and short half-life.(199) Optimization of 10074-G5 identified JY-3-094, with ca. fivefold increased potency in biochemical assays but reduced cytotoxicity due to poor cell permeability; ester prodrugs were shown to enhance permeability and intracellular half-life.(200,201) Further development of the benzofurazans is yet to be reported.
    Benzofurazans discovered by Bruick and coworkers (Figure 20) disrupt the assembly hypoxia inducible factors (HIFs), a transcription factor that is upregulated in many cancers.(202) Binding of the benzofurazans to the Per-Arnt-Sim (PAS) domain of HIF-2α prevents the formation of the active heterodimer complex;(203) heterodimerization of HIF-α and HIF-β is mediated through the PAS domain. The compounds are metabolically stable in cells (half-life ca. 14 h) and produced dose-dependent reductions in active HIF complex.(204) Based on proof-of-principle data the benzofurazans, having more favorable physical properties than second-generation inhibitor 76 (Figure 20), were licensed to Peloton Therapeutics for further development. SAR programs at Peloton(205) identified a key n → π*Ar binding interaction between Tyr-281 and the electron-deficient nitrobenzofurazan; replacement of the furazan and nitro groups with other strong EWGs maintained this interaction. Further optimization identified of a novel class of HIF-2α allosteric modulators(206) and clinical candidate PT2977 (Figure 20). PT2977 (MK-6482) is currently in phase III evaluation for advanced renal cell carcinoma (NCT04195750).

    Inhibitors of IDO1

    Inhibition of indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase 1 (IDO1) has received tremendous attention as a therapeutic target in immuno-oncology.(207) The furazan derivative INCB024360 (epacadostat; Incyte Corporation) is a potent and selective IDO1 inhibitor, with over 50 clinical trials initiated or proposed (clinicaltrials.gov). The furazan-based pharmacophore was identified by high-throughput screening; replacement of the furazan with other heterocycles was not tolerated.(208−211) SAR of the furazan moiety is disclosed in some patents,(212,213) but information is limited. Improvements to the oral bioavailability and half-life identified INCB024360 as the clinical candidate (Figure 21). Target engagement studies and preclinical investigation support an immune-mediated response to tumor suppression.(209,214)
    Binding of INCB024360 to the heme pocket of the IDO1 active site is mediated by the exocyclic hydroxyamidine oxygen atom; imidazole-based inhibitors such as NLG919 engage the heme via a heterocyclic ring nitrogen. Heme-binding of the hydroxyamidine is further stabilized by a H-bond with Ala-264 and two intramolecular H-bonds with the aniline and amino nitrogen atoms of INCB024360, which stabilize the active conformation. The benzene ring occupies a hydrophobic pocket proximal to the heme, engaging in a sulfur-fluorine bonding interaction with Cys-129. Interactions of the furazan moiety with Phe-163, Leu-234, and Phe-226 were also observed.
    Dose-escalation studies demonstrated INCB024360 was well-tolerated, reducing plasma kynurenine to “healthy” levels by two hours postadministration at doses of >100 mg twice-daily (bid.). Preliminary phase I/II data in small patient populations was encouraging, with combination therapy approaches (INCB024360 + monoclonal antibody treatments) improving overall patient responses.(215−219) Clinical trials (ECHO/KEYSTONE trials) were initiated to evaluate the efficacy of IDO1 blockade (INCB024360) in combination with other chemotherapy treatments; most trials were terminated following the results of a phase III trial (ECHO-301) in patients with metastatic melanoma, in which INCB024360 + pembrolizumab provided no advantage to pembrolizumab monotherapy.(220) It has been proposed that selective IDO1 inhibition is insufficient to sustain a therapeutic response, with compensatory pathways involving IDO2 and tryptophan 2,3-dioxygenase (TDO) implicated in disease progression during IDO1 blockade.(221)
    Academic research groups and pharmaceutical companies have developed analogues of INCB024360 (Figure 22) with improved PK properties;(222−227) dose-limiting toxicities (hyperglycemia) have been reported for INCB024360 which may be overcome by lower dosing/longer half-life. Development of pan-IDO/TDO inhibitors (82) has also been reported.(228) Dual action inhibitors targeting IDO/histone deacetylase (HDAC) activity (83) or IDO/DNA synthesis (84) have been disclosed;(229,230) preclinical reports have suggested that a combination of IDO1 inhibition with DNA damaging agents may enhance the efficacy of tumor regression versus chemotherapeutics which target DNA synthesis alone.(221)

    Kinase Inhibitors

    Akt (protein kinase B) is involved in regulating cellular processes such as glucose metabolism, apoptosis, proliferation and migration, making it an attractive target for oncology programs.(231) Researchers at GlaxoSmithKline discovered a furazanyl benzimidazole pharmacophore with broad spectrum kinase inhibition activity;(137−139) the furazan is an essential piece of the pharmacophore (Figure 14), engaging in two key H-bonding interactions in the hinge region of the ATP-binding site.(140) Development and SAR of the furazanyl benzimidazole pharmacophore is described above (see Inflammatory Disorders). Lead optimization identified GSK690693 (Figure 23) as a potent and selective inhibitor of Akt by exploiting a small pocket in the back cleft of the ATP-binding site (absent in related kinases MSK, ROCK, RSK).(139,232) Strong antiproliferative activity was observed in multiple cancer cell lines, with minimal toxicity in noncancerous human fibroblasts. Preclinical characterization demonstrated in vivo efficacy against xenograft models of ovarian, prostate and breast carcinoma (Table 16); the drug was well-tolerated in mice, although hyperglycemia was observed during treatment.(232,233) GSK690693 is the first Akt inhibitor to be evaluated clinically, with trials involving patients with advanced solid tumors, lymphoma (NCT00493818) and hematologic malignancies (NCT00666081);(234) the program was eventually terminated due to drug-related hyperglycemia and peripheral insulin resistance.
    Table 16. In Vivo Antitumor Effect of GSK690693 in Xenograft Micea
    xenograft (type)tumor volume decrease (%)
    BT474 (breast)46
    HCC-1954 (breast)65
    MDA-MB-453 (breast)27b
    SKOV3 (ovarian)58
    LNCaP (prostate)50
    PANC1 (pancreatic)+5b
    a

    30 mg/kg i.p. daily, 21 days.

    b

    Result is not significant (p > 0.05)

    Furazan-derived kinase inhibitors have been disclosed in other oncology programs (Figure 23): an approach involving inhibition of p70S6 (feedback inhibition of Akt signaling pathways) was investigated by Vertex Pharmaceuticals(235,236) (85). RSK1 inhibitors were claimed by Banyu Pharmaceutical Co. (a subsidiary of Merck) as antitumor agents(237) (86). Patents from 4SC disclosed a series of furazanopyrazines which inhibit multiple kinases and growth factors involved in cancer cell survival, proliferation, migration and metastasis(238) (87); targeting multiple aspects of tumorigenesis (“multiplex protein kinase inhibition”) could enable broad spectrum anticancer activity. Furazanyl triazoles identified by Pyrkov et al. inhibit phosphofructokinase, having antiproliferative effects against lung, colon and breast cancer cell lines(239) (88). More information regarding the development of these inhibitors or their efficacy as a cancer treatment has not been reported, nor are they listed in company pipelines.

    Other Approaches

    Upregulation of glutathione transferase (GST) is a known mechanism of chemoresistance in tumor cells; conjugation of drug molecules to glutathione (GSH) simulates efflux of the drug from the tumor environment. Nitrobenzofurazan inhibitors of GSTP1-1 identified by Caccuri and coworkers are effective inducers of apoptosis.(240,241) Nitrobenzofurazan is considered a PAINS motif with promiscuous reactivity; related derivative 4-chloro-7-nitrobenzofurazan is commonly employed as a fluorescent probe to study thiol conjugation in biological systems.(128) However, GST inhibitor NBDHEX (Figure 24) does not react with free GSH and displays only a weak interaction with the GSTP1-1 enzyme in vitro; inhibition of GST is observed only in the presence of both enzyme and GSH. Fluorometric analysis suggests the formation of a stable sigma complex between GSH and NBDHEX, causing dissociation of the JNK-GST complex and induction of apoptosis.(242)
    NBDHEX is well-tolerated,(243) with in vitro antiproliferative activity against many cancer cell lines (Table 17). However, in vivo efficacy is limited by poor bioavailability and limited selectivity over GSTM2-2 (expressed in noncancer cells).(244) Optimization of the physical properties identified MC3181 (Figure 24), having a more desirable activity/selectivity profile and enhanced solubility(245) (Table 17). MC3181 also reduces the invasiveness of melanoma tumors and lowers the incidence of metastasis in vitro.(246) Preclinical evaluation of MC3181 in melanoma xenograft models is encouraging; MC3181 was more efficacious than Temozolomide in treating melanomas resistant to BRAF inhibitors (e.g., vemurafenib).(247,248) Further improvements to the metabolic stability and bioavailability (pro-drug approaches) is ongoing.(249,250)
    Table 17. In Vitro and Preclinical in Vivo Activity of NBDHEX and MC3181
    parameterNBDHEXMC3181
    IC50 (GSTP1-1)0.8 μM2.6 μM
    IC50 (GSTM2-2)<0.01 μM0.08 μM
    solubility (pH 7.4)a0.10 mM5.0 mM
    EC50 (A375)0.37 μM0.77 μM
    EC50 (U-2OS)0.9 μM1.1 μM
    EC50 (MM-B1)1.3 μM1.6 μM
    EC50 (MCF-7)1.6 μM1.5 μM
    EC50 (COLO 205)5.3 μM6.5 μM
    EC50 (HT-29)11.0 μM15.8 μM
    tumor red. (A375)b65%c60%d
    a

    Potassium phosphate buffer solution.

    b

    Tumor reduction in melanoma xenograft mouse.

    c

    40 mg/kg p.o. once daily for 10 consecutive days; tumor weight reduction.

    d

    8.0 mg/kg IV q1Dx5/3; tumor volume reduction.

    Regulation of p21, a cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor, has been proposed as an oncology drug target,(251) but this approach is complicated by the complex network of p21-related activity in biological functions.(252) A screening program reported by Baden-Wuerttemberg Stiftung identified furazanopyrazines as potent and selective inhibitors of p21 activity(253) (Figure 25, compound 89). Selectivity (greater than twofold) over p53 and its target genes (inhibition of MDM2 <50%) was demonstrated in vitro. Inhibition of p21 activity is proposed to occur at the transcriptional level by preventing the association of p53 to the p21-promoter sequence. Other nonfurazanyl chemotypes with good potency and selectivity were also disclosed (Figure 25, compounds 90, 91). Furazanopyrazines claimed as antitumor agents by Compass Pharmaceuticals inhibit proliferation of patient-derived sarcoma and ovarian tumor cells(254) (Figure 25, compounds 92–94), but a MoA was not disclosed.

    Antimicrobials

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Antibacterial

    The prominence of antibiotic resistance and the estimated global burden of multidrug resistant pathogens(255) has prompted research efforts to identify novel chemotypes. Furazan derivatives are known to exhibit a range of antimicrobial activities, including antibiotic, antifungal, and antipest,(256−260) yet evidence of selectivity over eukaryotic cells is seldom provided. A report from Abbot Laboratories identified furazanopyrazines (Figure 26, compound 95) as broad-spectrum antibiotics with good selectivity over eukaryotic cell lines;(261) antibiotic activity was observed in H. influenzae, S. aureus, and S. pneumoniae with no observable cytotoxicity in yeast (C. albicans) or human lymphocytes (Table 18). Benzofurazan-derived inhibitors of flavodoxin (Figure 26, compounds 96, 97) are reported to be effective against H. pylori infection in vitro (Table 18) and in vivo (Table 19). The compounds were well-tolerated in mice with no observable toxicity at the administered doses (histopathological examination). Efficacy in metronidazole-resistant H. pylori strains was also demonstrated.(262−265) Inhibition of iron acquisition pathways via bacterial siderophores has been proposed as a therapeutic strategy to treat multidrug resistant pathogens; furazan-derived inhibitors of BasE (no known human homologues) exhibit antibiotic activity against A. baumannii, of which there are multiple drug resistant forms(266) (Figure 26, compound 98). The binding affinity of these compounds for isolated BasE is quite strong,(267) suggesting that live cell (MIC = 0.5 mM) and in vivo potency of these compounds can be enhanced through medicinal chemistry.
    Table 18. MIC Values of Furazan Derivatives 95–99 for Various Pathogenic Bacteria
    compoundH. influenzaeS. aureusS. pneumoniaeH. pylori SS1aH. pylori NCTC 11637b
    95a (R = F)4.3 μM0.28 mM0.28 mM  
    95b (R = Cl)4.0 μM64 μM0.50 mM  
    95c (R = Br)3.4 μM55 μM0.22 mM  
    95d (R = OPh)26 μM13 μM0.21 mM  
    99 0.25 mMc0.25 mMd

    b

    d

    e

    Table 19. In Vivo Efficacy of 96 and 97 in H. pylori (SS1) Infected Mice
    compounddose p.o. (mg/kg)ainfection cures (%)b
    961.043
    9720060
    a

    Administered for 8 consecutive days, first dose 8 days postinfection.

    b

    Measured 8 days after final dose.

    Biofilm formation is associated with the majority of microbial infections and is known to enhance antibiotic resistance and virulence.(268) The biofilm matrix contains a dense array of microbial hydrolases and proteases, which can negatively impact drug stability. Das et al. identified oximinofurazans (Figure 26, compound 99) with antibiotic activity against S. aureus and P. aeruginosa which also disrupt the associated biofilm (Table 20); antibiotic activity of 99 against planktonic cell cultures is comparable to azithromycin and tobramycin(269) (Table 18). A reduction of bacterial motility and reduced adherence properties of the biofilm matrix are implicated in the observed biofilm attenuation. Secretion of microbial hydrolases was also reduced. Limited hemolysis was observed in red blood cells treated with the furazan derivatives which implies selectivity for the pathogen over host cells.
    Table 20. Reduction in Biofilm Formation of S. aureus and S. pneumoniae by Uredofurazan 99 and Antibiotics Azithromycin (AZM) and Tobramycin (TBM)
    compounddose (μM)S. aureus (%)S. pneumoniae (%)
    99637773
    AZMa7.648 
    TBMa13 50
    a

    Included as positive controls; data were obtained under the same assay conditions as uredofurazan 99.

    Antiparasitic

    4-Hydroxyfurazan-5-carboxylic acid (Figure 27, compound 100) was identified as an effective inhibitor of P. falciparum lactate dehydrogenase (pfLDH), an emerging target for antimalarial drug development.(270) Of note, activity was maintained in a P. falciparum strain (K1) resistant to chloroquine, pyrimethamine, and cycloguanilil (Table 21). The furazan engages in a key H-bonding interaction with Ser-245 of pfLDH; this interaction is absent in the human homologue, imparting selectivity for the pathogen over the host. Drugs which target this region of pfLDH may preclude the formation of a viable drug-resistant strain, as mutation of Ser-245 produce severe reductions in the catalytic efficiency of pfLDH. PK studies (Table 22) demonstrated rapid absorption and good plasma levels of the drug, but a short half-life. Poor cell penetration is also expected, as 100 exists as the dianion under physiological conditions. Nonetheless, a moderate reduction in parasitic load was observed in vivo (Table 22). Other research programs have disclosed (benzo)furazan derivatives with antiparasitic activity against T. brucei(271) and L. donovani,(272) but the (benzo)furazan moiety appears to be interchangeable with other heterocycles and the biological activity is modest.
    Table 21. In Vitro Characterization of 100–102
    parameter100101102
    Ki (pfLDH)210 nM470 nM290 nM
    EC50 (pf 3D7)a22.5 μM74.4 μM75.3 μM
    EC90 (pf 3D7)a75.9 μM>200 μM>170 μM
    EC50 (pf K1)b18.6 μM 144 μM
    EC50 (KB)c0.64 mM  
    EC50 (HeLa)c1.3 mM  
    a

    Drug-sensitive strain.

    b

    Drug-resistant strain.

    c

    Mammalian eukaryotic cells. pf = P. falciparum.

    Table 22. In Vivo PK and Efficacy 100 and 101 as Anti-Plasmodium Therapeutics (Preclinical Model)
     Cmax (μM)t1/2 (h) 
    drugap.o.i.p.p.o.i.p.parasite reduction (%)b
    1001381961.31.341
    1011531581.61.130
    a

    Administered at 100 mg/kg.

    b

    10 mg/kg chloroquine results in 100% parasite clearance.

    Antiviral

    Nitrobenzofurazans which inhibit the viral RNA polymerase complex were disclosed by Pike Pharma as anti-influenza agents(273,274) (Figure 28). Viral RNA polymerase is highly conserved across many strains, making it an attractive drug target. The benzofurazan participates in a π-stacking interaction with Trp-706 and H-bonding with Gln-408, while the nitro group forms an electrostatic interaction with Lys-643.(275,276) Antiviral activity against influenza type A, type B, and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) was demonstrated in vitro.(273,274) The MoA involves benzofurazan-mediated disruption of the PA-PB1 subunit interaction, leading to RNA polymerase inhibition. The anti-influenza activity of benzofurazans was unknown prior to these reports.

    Other Indications

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Mitochondrial uncouplers induce proton leak from the inner membrane space to the mitochondrial matrix independent of the ATP synthase machinery, increasing cellular metabolism. Disorders linked to mitochondrial oxidative stress or metabolism can be treated using mitochondrial uncouplers. For example, 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP) has been used to treat obesity. Most mitochondrial uncouplers also depolarize the plasma membrane, resulting in off-target cytotoxicity; DNP was removed from the market in 1938 due to a narrow therapeutic window and severe adverse effects. The furazanopyrazine BAM15 was identified as a selective uncoupler of the mitochondrial membrane, having no impact on the plasma membrane.(277) The compound is well-tolerated in vivo, producing therapeutic responses in models of kidney injury,(277) diet-induced obesity,(278) insulin resistance (diabetes)(279) and fatty liver disease.(280) SAR studies determined the furazanopyrazine is essential, providing the requisite balance of lipophilic character and acidity,(281,282) and replacement with other heterocycles led to decreased activity(283) (Figure 29). Optimization of the activity, physical properties and PK profile identified hydroxy-substituted furazanopyrazines as efficient mitochondrial uncouplers(284) (Table 23). The advanced lead SHS4121705 is currently being investigated by Continuum Biosciences as a treatment for nonalcoholic steatohepatitis.(282)
    Table 23. Physical Properties and Biological Activity of BAM15 and Preclinical Lead SHS4121705
    a

    Measured in phosphate-buffered saline, pH 7.4.

    b

    Concentration which stimulates 50% of maximum achievable OCR.

    c

    Measured relative to baseline OCR.

    d

    Dose of 10 mg/kg (p.o.). OCR = oxygen consumption rate.

    A series of P-gp ligands have been disclosed by Colabufo and coworkers as positron emission topography (PET) imaging tools(285) and cotherapeutic agents to mitigate efflux-related drug resistance(286) (Figure 30). The addition of a pendant furazan to the established pharmacophore MC70 significantly enhanced potency and selectivity (MDR1/MRP1); the furazan moiety forms an additional H-bonding interaction with Gln-195.(287) The furazan derivatives could enhance the efficacy of chemotherapeutics: MC70 enhances doxorubicin response in breast cancer cell lines.(286) Development of imaging agents to study P-gp function in vivo has also been proposed. Novo Nordisk identified a class of furazans which are selective inhibitors of GSK-3β and were investigated as therapeutic agents to treat diabetes(236,288) (Figure 31). Stimulation of glycogen synthase activity was observed in tissue cultures (ca. threefold stimulation at 10 μM), suggesting good permeability of the compounds.(289)In vivo efficacy and other preclinical data have not been reported.

    Outlook

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    (Benzo)furazan derivatives show a range of interesting biology, with furazanyl benzimidazoles, furazanopyrazines, and uredo/amido furazans being most prevalent in drug discovery programs. The ability to generate benzo-fused systems provides chemical space unique to that of the 1,2,4- or 1,3,4-oxadiazole isomers; a balance of lipophilic character and polarity is achieved. Nonetheless, the prevalence of furazans in drug discovery programs and drug molecules is considerably low. Furazan derivatives are often identified in high-throughput screening programs, likely due to a range of possible binding interactions (H-bonding, π-stacking, and polar or van der Waals interactions), but are seldom carried through development. The identification of benzofurazans (particularly nitrobenzofurazans) as a PAINS motif, having promiscuous reactivity, would explain the low incidence of furazan-containing drugs. Removal of such “red flags” are typical first steps of a lead optimization program. However, one must carefully analyze benzofurazan-containing structures that have been described as PAINS.(290) The benzofurazan group is an electron deficient ring system; therefore, the presence of a leaving group ortho to the furazan moiety could permit nucleophilic attachment and potential off-target reactivity within a screening assay. These types of structures, as with any highly electron deficient heterocyclic ring system, should be evaluated carefully. Also, as with nitro-containing compounds, benzofurazans have the potential to be florescent; secondary screening with orthogonal assays should be performed when fluoresce-based assays are employed.
    The biology and pharmacology described in this Review demonstrate that selective target engagement can be obtained through standard SAR practices to generate safe and efficacious furazan-derived molecules. Given that furazans are less common in the patent and academic literature, this chemotype may also offer interesting opportunities to explore new chemical space in future drug discovery programs.

      2
      Progress in the chemistry of nitrogen-, oxygen- and sulfur-containing heterocyclic systems
      Makhova, Nina N.; Belen'kii, Leonid I.; Gazieva, Galina A.; Dalinger, Igor L.; Konstantinova, Lidia S.; Kuznetsov, Vladimir V.; Kravchenko, Angelina N.; Krayushkin, Mikhail M.; Rakitin, Oleg A.; Starosotnikov, Alexey M.; Fershtat, Leonid L.; Shevelev, Svyatoslav A.; Shirinian, Valerik Z.; Yarovenko, Vladimir N.
      Russian Chemical Reviews (2020), 89 (1), 55-124CODEN: RCRVAB; ISSN:0036-021X. (IOP Publishing Ltd.)
      The review is devoted to modern trends in the chem. of nitrogen-, oxygen- and sulfur-contg. monocyclic, polynuclear and benzo(hetero)annulated heterocyclic compds. Methods for the synthesis and chem. reactivity of furazan, furoxan, thiazole, thiadiazole, dithiazole, thiophene, glycoluril, imidazotriazine, diaziridine and other heterocycles are discussed. Characteristic features of reactions depending on the structure of the starting compds., intermediates and reaction medium (org. solvents, ionic liqs.) and mechanistic aspects of the most interesting transformations are considered. Data on the biol. activities and prospects for practical applications of the indicated heterocyclic systems are presented.

      4
      The new era of 1,2,4-oxadiazoles
      Pace, Andrea; Pierro, Paola
      Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2009), 7 (21), 4337-4348CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      This review covers the synthesis, the chem. and photochem. reactivity, and the use of 1,2,4-oxadiazoles in materials and as bioactive compds. Further, the material in this survey includes some historical background, general features, state-of-the-art applications together with a crit. discussion about current limitations and suggestions for future developments.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXht1Gksb7E&md5=9314bd3fbc51b2e5bc1a6eafa44646a4
    5. 5
      Bostrom, J.; Hogner, A.; Llinas, A.; Wellner, E.; Plowright, A. T. Oxadiazoles in medicinal chemistry. J. Med. Chem. 2012, 55 (5), 1817– 1830,  DOI: 10.1021/jm2013248
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Oxadiazoles in medicinal chemistry
      Bostrom Jonas; Hogner Anders; Llinas Antonio; Wellner Eric; Plowright Alleyn T
      Journal of medicinal chemistry (2012), 55 (5), 1817-30 ISSN:.
      Oxadiazoles are five-membered heteroaromatic rings containing two carbons, two nitrogens, and one oxygen atom, and they exist in different regioisomeric forms. Oxadiazoles are frequently occurring motifs in druglike molecules, and they are often used with the intention of being bioisosteric replacements for ester and amide functionalities. The current study presents a systematic comparison of 1,2,4- and 1,3,4-oxadiazole matched pairs in the AstraZeneca compound collection. In virtually all cases, the 1,3,4-oxadiazole isomer shows an order of magnitude lower lipophilicity (log D), as compared to its isomeric partner. Significant differences are also observed with respect to metabolic stability, hERG inhibition, and aqueous solubility, favoring the 1,3,4-oxadiazole isomers. The difference in profile between the 1,2,4 and 1,3,4 regioisomers can be rationalized by their intrinsically different charge distributions (e.g., dipole moments). To facilitate the use of these heteroaromatic rings, novel synthetic routes for ready access of a broad spectrum of 1,3,4-oxadiazoles, under mild conditions, are described.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC383pt1Oisw%253D%253D&md5=b934995431ced1be297e6f126262f3cb
    6. 6
      de Oliveira, C. S.; Lira, B. F.; Barbosa-Filho, J. M.; Lorenzo, J. G.; de Athayde-Filho, P. F. Synthetic approaches and pharmacological activity of 1,3,4-oxadiazoles: a review of the literature from 2000–2012. Molecules 2012, 17 (9), 10192– 10231,  DOI: 10.3390/molecules170910192
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Synthetic approaches and pharmacological activity of 1,3,4-oxadiazoles: a review of the literature from 2000-2012
      de Oliveira Cledualdo Soares; Lira Bruno Freitas; Barbosa-Filho Jose Maria; Lorenzo Jorge Goncalo Fernandez; de Athayde-Filho Petronio Filgueiras
      Molecules (Basel, Switzerland) (2012), 17 (9), 10192-231 ISSN:.
      This review provides readers with an overview of the main synthetic methodologies for 1,3,4-oxadiazole derivatives, and of their broad spectrum of pharmacological activities as reported over the past twelve years.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC38bhslSjsA%253D%253D&md5=4f09fb45888e071f2601ff846fc83d9d
    7. 7
      Biernacki, K.; Dasko, M.; Ciupak, O.; Kubinski, K.; Rachon, J.; Demkowicz, S. Novel 1,2,4-oxadiazole derivatives in drug discovery. Pharmaceuticals 2020, 13 (6), 111,  DOI: 10.3390/ph13060111
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Novel 1,2,4-oxadiazole derivatives in drug discovery
      Biernacki, Karol; Dasko, Mateusz; Ciupak, Olga; Kubinski, Konrad; Rachon, Janusz; Demkowicz, Sebastian
      Pharmaceuticals (2020), 13 (6), 111CODEN: PHARH2; ISSN:1424-8247. (MDPI AG)
      A review. Five-membered 1,2,4-oxadiazole heterocyclic ring has received considerable attention because of its unique bioisosteric properties and an unusually wide spectrum of biol. activities. Thus, it is a perfect framework for the novel drug development. After a century since the 1,2,4-oxadiazole have been discovered, the uncommon potential attracted medicinal chemists' attention, leading to the discovery of a few presently accessible drugs contg. 1,2,4-oxadiazole unit. It is worth noting that the interest in a 1,2,4-oxadiazoles' biol. application has been doubled in the last fifteen years. Herein, after a concise historical introduction, we present a comprehensive overview of the recent achievements in the synthesis of 1,2,4-oxadiazole-based compds. and the major advances in their biol. applications in the period of the last five years as well as brief remarks on prospects for further development.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXhvFyktLzN&md5=98d1ab4ede67a8ff5a872e37c1a4f044
    8. 8
      Fershtat, L. L.; Makhova, N. N. 1,2,5-Oxadiazole-based high-energy-density materials: Synthesis and performance. ChemPlusChem 2020, 85 (1), 13– 42,  DOI: 10.1002/cplu.201900542
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      1,2,5-Oxadiazole-Based High-Energy-Density Materials: Synthesis and Performance
      Fershtat, Leonid L.; Makhova, Nina N.
      ChemPlusChem (2020), 85 (1), 13-42CODEN: CHEMM5; ISSN:2192-6506. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      This Review covers the synthesis and performance of the most promising 1,2,5-oxadiazole-based high-energy d. materials (HEDMs). These materials comprise a 1,2,5-oxadiazole subunit as a key structural motif linked to various acyclic explosophoric groups or to nitrogen-rich and nitrogen-oxygen azoles: 1,2,4-triazole, tetrazole, 1,2,4- and 1,3,4-oxadiazoles. Energetic alliances of two and more 1,2,5-oxadiazole rings linked directly or through heteroatom spacers are also presented. Particular attention is devoted to the installation of different explosophores: nitro, nitramino, azo, azoxy, dinitromethyl, trinitroethyl moieties and their combination. Promising environmentally benign energetic materials with high detonation velocity and pressure, and outstanding insensitivity are summarized. Overall, the presented materials may be considered as next-generation high-performance energetic materials that are superior to commonly used traditional explosives (TNT, PETN, RDX, HMX).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXitFantbbF&md5=b2a1e1115a4b19b7afc947ffcec53b2c
    9. 9
      Fershtat, L. L.; Makhova, N. N. Advances in the synthesis of non-annelated polynuclear heterocyclic systems comprising the 1,2,5-oxadiazole ring. Russ. Chem. Rev. 2016, 85 (10), 1097– 1145,  DOI: 10.1070/RCR4619
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Advances in the synthesis of non-annelated polynuclear heterocyclic systems comprising the 1,2,5-oxadiazole ring
      Fershtat, Leonid L.; Makhova, Nina N.
      Russian Chemical Reviews (2016), 85 (10), 1097-1145CODEN: RCRVAB; ISSN:0036-021X. (IOP Publishing Ltd.)
      This review is concerned with recently developed synthetic methods for non-annelated polynuclear heterocyclic systems that incorporate, along with a furazan and(or) furoxan ring, polynitrogen and nitrogen oxygen heterocycles (1,2,4 and 1,3,4 oxadiazole, 1,2,3 and 1,2,4 triazole, tetrazole, pyrazole, sym triazine, 1,2,4,5 tetrazine and so on) linked via C C or C N bonds or heteroat. [N, O, S, N N, N(O) N] bridges. Methods for prepg. assemblies in which a furazan ring and(or) a furoxan ring are linked to one another by C C bonds or heteroatoms (N, O, S) are surveyed. Potential applications of the synthesized structures as pharmacol. active and high energy compds. are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Advances in the chemistry of furazano[3,4-b]pyrazines and their analogues
      Sheremetev, A. B.; Yudin, I. L.
      Russian Chemical Reviews (2003), 72 (1), 87-100CODEN: RCRVAB; ISSN:0036-021X. (Turpion Ltd.)
      A review. The published data on the methods for the synthesis of furazans fused to six-membered heterocycles with two heteroatoms in positions 1 and 4, their reactivities and practical applications are considered and systematized. The bibliog. includes 89 refs. A review.

      Cerecetto, H.; Porcal, W. Pharmacological properties of furoxans and benzofuroxans: Recent developments. Mini-Rev. Med. Chem. 2005, 5 (1), 57– 71,  DOI: 10.2174/1389557053402864
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      Pharmacological properties of furoxans and benzofuroxans: Recent developments
      Cerecetto, Hugo; Porcal, Williams
      Mini-Reviews in Medicinal Chemistry (2005), 5 (1), 57-71CODEN: MMCIAE; ISSN:1389-5575. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. The chem. of furoxans (1, 2, 5-oxadiazole-2-oxides) and benzofuroxans (benzo[1, 2-c]1, 2, 5-oxadiazole-1-oxides) is very well known. These systems are widely used in org. chem. as intermediate compds. for the synthesis of numerous heterocycles. In the other hand, furoxan and benzofuroxan derivs. were extensively studied as bioactive compds. They possess remarkable biol. activities, such as anti-microbial and anti-parasitic properties, mutagenic, immunosuppressive and anticancer effects, anti-aggregating and vasorelaxant activity, among others. In some cases, mol. mode of action was proposed. Recently, the research and development in the medicinal chem. of these systems have produced hybrid compds. in which furoxan or benzofuroxan moieties together with a classical drug moieties are present in a single mol. So, new anti-ulcer drugs, calcium channel modulators and vasodilator derivs. were described and they are currently in study. In this presentation recent developments in the medicinal chem. of furoxans will be reviewed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXot1antQ%253D%253D&md5=18da9801499316246bc2313c9b734241

      Trifonov, R. E.; Ostrovskii, V. A. Basicity of 2-phenyl-5-R-1,3,4-oxadiazoles. Chem. Heterocycl. Compd. 2006, 42 (5), 657– 664,  DOI: 10.1007/s10593-006-0142-y
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17
      Basicity of 2-phenyl-5-R-1,3,4-oxadiazoles
      Trifonov, R. E.; Ostrovskii, V. A.
      Chemistry of Heterocyclic Compounds (New York, NY, United States) (2006), 42 (5), 657-664CODEN: CHCCAL; ISSN:0009-3122. (Springer)
      The authors have studied the basicity of 2-phenyl-5-R-1,3,4-oxadiazoles (R = H, Me, CH2Ph, t-Bu, CH2Cl, CCl3, CF3) in aq. sulfuric acid solns. These compds. are weak org. bases (pKBH+ is -1.8 to - 5.2). The values of pKBH+ detd. on the H0 and X acidity function scales agree well with each other. The substituent at the 5 position has a substantial effect on the basicity of the 1,3,4-oxadiazole ring.
